channel.title: Nature Materials
channel.description: Nature Materials is a multidisciplinary journal aimed at bringing together cutting-edge research across the entire spectrum of materials science and technology. Nature Materials covers all applied and fundamental aspects of the synthesis/processing, structure/composition, properties and performance of materials. Nature Materials provides a forum for the development of a common identity among materials scientists while encouraging researchers to cross established subdisciplinary lines. To achieve this, Nature Materials takes an interdisciplinary, integrated and balanced approach to all areas of materials research while fostering the exchange of ideas between scientists involved in different communities.
channel.dc:rights: © 2025 Macmillan Publishers Limited, part of Springer Nature. All rights reserved.

item.title: Ultrafast surface melting of orbital order in La<sub>0.5</sub>Sr<sub>1.5</sub>MnO<sub>4</sub>
item.content:encoded:
Nature Materials, Published online: 13 October 2025; doi:10.1038/s41563-025-02379-4

Time-resolved surface X-ray scattering is used to probe how light manipulates orbital order at the surface of a manganite. Femtosecond light is found to generate incoherent atomic disorder on an ultrafast timescale, consistent with the localization of polarons.
item.dc:title: Ultrafast surface melting of orbital order in La<sub>0.5</sub>Sr<sub>1.5</sub>MnO<sub>4</sub>

item.title: Near-100% spontaneous rolling up of polar van der Waals materials
item.content:encoded:
Nature Materials, Published online: 13 October 2025; doi:10.1038/s41563-025-02357-w

Spontaneous scrolling in two-dimensional polar van der Waals materials, driven by intrinsic out-of-plane electric polarization, enables the scalable production of nanoscrolls and their heterostructures.
item.dc:title: Near-100% spontaneous rolling up of polar van der Waals materials

item.title: Using light to print metal oxides
item.content:encoded:
Nature Materials, Published online: 10 October 2025; doi:10.1038/s41563-025-02371-y

A plasmonic printing technology is developed to enable rapid, room-temperature, scalable fabrication of all-metal oxide thin-film transistors and circuits.
item.dc:title: Using light to print metal oxides
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Dickey

item.title: Giant photoconductance at infinite-layer nickelate/SrTiO<sub>3</sub> interfaces via an optically induced high-mobility electron gas
item.content:encoded:
Nature Materials, Published online: 10 October 2025; doi:10.1038/s41563-025-02363-y

The electronic ground state of a correlated oxide interface is reversibly switched by light. Stemming from interfacial reconstructions, electrostatic confinement and photodoping, this effect opens a path towards engineering the optical response of oxides.
item.dc:title: Giant photoconductance at infinite-layer nickelate/SrTiO<sub>3</sub> interfaces via an optically induced high-mobility electron gas
